Expectation1: Assist patients with daily living activities such as bathing, dressing, and eating
Situation1: A patient is recovering from a recent surgery and requires more careful assistance to move and get dressed.
Situation2: The polls close for good tonight, and this moment is the voter’s sole opportunity to present the mandated ID.
Story: I glance at the clock on the wall, my heart pounding. Mrs. Lee, just out of surgery, winces as I help her sit up. She’s frail, her movements slow and uncertain. I know she needs me to help her get dressed and settled before dinner, and I can’t rush her—she trusts me to be gentle, to keep her safe. But my mind keeps drifting to my purse in the break room, where my ID sits ready. The polls close in less than an hour, and this is my only chance to vote. I promised myself I’d make my voice heard this year, but Mrs. Lee’s comfort and dignity are in my hands right now. My supervisor expects me to give every patient my full attention, but the world outside expects me to show up as a responsible citizen. I feel torn, guilt and anxiety twisting inside me as I weigh the needs of the person in front of me against the duty I owe to my community.
